posts.sub: How can I ever thank my mother for what she has done?
posts.com: My mother is sick in the hospital right now. The prognosis is looking really bad. She is pretty much exactly what this mom in this picture is like. She was always baking cookies, and cakes every day for us. She made sure we always ate delicious foods growing up, because her passion was cooking. But she never talked about feelings type things ever. If you ever talked about emotional feelings, she would quickly shut off or say, Ill go check up on the bake. so she was useless about emotionally supporting us. Well now that she is dying, she pretends it is not even happening, even when she is suffering on the bed. She still only cares about making sure the house hold is in order, the groceries are in order, and the lunches are packed. I later learned that why my mom was this way is because her dad abused her mom physically. She grew up in a household in ireland that her mom dealt with the trauma of being abused when her dad got drunk. It rubbed off on her. All she ever wanted to do was create a happy spotless home, even as my pos dad cheated on her, she moved out for a couple weeks and worked as a chef in the bertuccis restaurant, but she decided to forgive him and move back in. My dad was complaining about the pasta last week and I wanted to kill him. How could he care about pasta when she is sick and dying? How do I thank her for what she did for us? How do I forgive her for being emotionally distant? I just want my mommy back. She is too young to die. She is only 59.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>27922705
Unlike SSRIs and antipsychotics, you can go cold turkey on stimulants if you want. If you have ADHD, life is going to kind of suck without it, but you can manage. Word is that the stimulant shortage is really the gov pissing themselves because they let oxycontin go out of control and are trying to lock down the next big wave of prescription abuse. There's is no particular shortage, just way more regulatory hoops than before.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>27922705
You'll feel groggy, sleep a lot, eat a lot, and not have much energy for the first few weeks. It takes a while to feel fully normal again and get rid of the brainfog. Like, a month or two. If it's something you want to do, you'll have to tough it out. It was totally worth it for me, though. Just remember that your appetite will be crazy, and you're probably not used to having to watch what you eat. I used to come home from work and eat a whole pot of pasta, pizza, chicken nuggets, whatever because it makes your metabolism so fast and you don't eat much during the day. When I quit, I gained 30 lbs. within a few months and am still trying to get rid of it. Just something to keep in mind. Baby carrots are nice to snack on, and potatos are good for keeping you full without many calories. That's the only part that sucked about quitting after the first month or so.

If you have time, you could cut your dosage in half for a while before stopping completely, which might lessen some of the symptoms.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>27922705

You should imo.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
As someone who is being treated for ADHD, I can say that you won't die from not taking Adderall. With this being said, Desoxyn has the potential to impact serotonin in a manner which Adderall won't.

You could try DMAA or DMHA if you absolutely have to, but I wouldn't recommend it except if other treatments don't work. Neither are as good as Desoxyn or Adderall.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>27925053
>Is there like a hermit mentality or meditation or something that can prepare my mind for the rest of my life?
Short answer yes. However, I think instead of searching for gain, you would do better to search for loss. That appears more the issue. Not to gain a new mentality or a new perspective or a new mindset, but to lose the ones you have now. You need to lose what isn't currently serving you before there is room to gain what will serve you.

>people just have a better time when I'm not around.
>I'm just very boring I think.
>Probably creepy too because I have so little social experience.
>I think I'm a very pathetic person
>if I was someone else I wouldn't want to be near me
>at this point in my life I know it's over and I am going to be alone for the rest of my life.

Lose all of these. They are very likely untrue. But, irrespective of their truth, they are not serving you. They are hindering and hurting you. They hold you back and likely act as self-fulfilling prophecies. This self-abusive mindset sabotages you, and is very likely the proximate cause of the current state of suffering you now find yourself in.

For something tangible and actionable, you could learn about self-compassion and learn to more accurately analyze the root of these types of negative statements. Then you learn to replace them with positive ones. Alternatively, there's things like CBT where you likewise learn to analyze these types of cognitive distortions. Remove and replace. That's the common theme. Both involve practice and application, and that practice will retrain your thoughts and your behaviors so that the bad thoughts are no longer automatic. The self-abuse is no longer automatic. The good becomes automatic.

Buddhism. Stoicism. Taoism. Et cetera. There are many paths, but be sure of this: you need to lose before you can gain. You'll find that theme in many.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: It wasn't me being just so unlikable or ugly or having zero social skills or the world being oh so cruel that I didn't have friends. I didn't have friends because I didn't put any effort in to talk to people at all, or to follow up with them or organize and plan things with them. I just simply didn't work at it. And when I tried, I convinced myself I was fucking it up somehow because I was so hurt by all the betrayals and broken promises or other disappointments. Truthfully that is normal and everyone experiences that, and people who have good friends have been through this more than anyone else. It's just something you have to keep trying at. No one just skips ahead to the good parts, no matter how it seems. I remember in middle/high school I used to be so envious of people who were sociable and athletic and good looking and I thought that it was because they were simply *just* that much better than me. I spent so much time resenting them that I thought I was superior because I experienced suffering and was deep and introspective due to being lonely and having no meaningful experiences in life and with other people (lol). I was putting out all the signals to others that I didn't want to be bothered, and then was shocked when people just left me alone. In solely my own imagination was I someone who was warm, friendly, and easygoing. I'm glad I realized this and also that my incredibly low self esteem at the time was due to me being incompetent due to the lack of self awareness, rather than just me being born a loser. This meant I could change it. Those people who were sociable and good looking put a TON of effort into doing every little thing, and I mean really everything, they were so much smarter and deliberate than I gave them credit for. I realized I could do the same thing too. I am no longer intimidated or mystified by people just seem perfect because people see me that way too now, and I can clearly see all the things they did to be who they are.

>>27923735
Depends how autistic you are, and how good you are at masking.

The more uncomfortable you are to be around, the less sympathy people generally have for you. Instinctively, autistic behaviour can come across like a threat to people who don't know you.
Eg: The other day I was shopping with my brother and stumbled across a pop-up shop that was outside an autism therapy/support centre. When we went inside to see the rest of the shop, I got swamped by a bunch of autistic people who all wanted to talk to us (see: me). For a moment, I was really uncomfortable and felt vaguely panicked as I tried to adjust and gauge just how tardy each person was so I could figure out how to speak to them all, but the feeling quickly went away as I got used to each one as we talked. It did freak me out when the tardiest among them approached me from just outside my field of vision and tried to hug me and kiss my cheek. If a stranger had done that shit on the street I would have beat him to a pulp. The only reason this guy didn't get punched was because he was clearly very spergy and possibly didn't realise the boundary he'd crossed.

Also, the more excuses you make for yourself, the less sympathy people have for you.
One of my flatmates has aspergers. He's fucking dope. He's always working towards managing that shit and leading a healthier life. He's very cool. Even when his sperginess comes out, it's not an issue. My other flatmate believes he may be autistic too, but refuses to get diagnosed or seek therapy to help him manage that shit - despite very clearly making people uncomfortable and knowing it's an issue. I have zero sympathy for that cunt. I prefer the guy who kissed me. Taking responsibility for one's autism and clearly communicating it goes a long fucking way.

It’s not the end of the world if it’s a guy because she could just be having fun, but have a good excuse for if it’s her man. My go to is “it’s party, let’s have fun” and try dancing with the man. It may seem weird, but no dude wants to be the asshole who started the fight if it looks like you’re not trying to steal his girl.

Second, no drinks. Women who accept drinks in a club only want free stuff. If the nightclub is your game and you want to spend money, pay for table service. It’s expensive, but it adds prestige, you get s place to take her to so you can talk, and there’s drinks there anyway.
The whole point of the night club is to dance and have fun, so make yourself charming and fun. Look goofy but with a smile. Unless you’re a world class dancer, you will not impress her with your moves. It’s all about body language in s club. If you can get her to dance with you for at least 2 songs, then you have a good chance of asking if she wants to sit down and talk. But even when that happens, be fun. Talk about how you like to go out and blow off steam. Or, if you’ve got the real acting chops, point to some random guys and say “I came here with some friends, but they weren’t much fun. So I struck out in my own.” Make it seem like you’re getting away with something mischievous by being with her, everyone wants to be the partner in crime

Honestly, the way you build up confidence is to approach random groups of people, especially the ones with guys. Just walk up to them and introduce yourself. Say you usually go to a different club and are checking out the scene. Ask if they come often and or not where they recommend. Make yourself seem like a nomad who sees value in their input without giving them control of the conversation. Then, after a few minutes, move on to the next group. When you do this, you realize that everyone in the club is just there for a good time and no one will think much about you for a few seconds. Plus, eventually your routine can form. You can reference either people, maybe say “hey have you seen that dude’s jacket? What’s with that!” Or something silly to start the convo. Maybe make some jokes about the DJ. If you make it apparent you’ve met most people in the club, you instantly become the cool guy there and girls will want to chat a little longer. And if they tell you to screw off, shrug and dance away. Make it their loss

It depends on the scenario. I have never considered myself particularly handsome or cute. Some girls have called me both, but I generally get rated a 5 or 6/10 in face rate threads.
I get a lot of attention by just talking to them. Having something funny to say or doing an activity together.
One time I was out with an ex girlfriend and her friends for her birthday. We were at a museum and we met her Vietnamese friend. Very cute girl around 28 years old. Our first real interaction was me getting her to stand on a scale that told her what she would weigh in mars, jokingly of course. Then we talked about love of travel and our interests while the whole group was at dinner and we traded numbers and set a date for the following weekend. We ended up dating for a few months but it didn’t work because she was looking for marriage and I wasn’t in a position to marry yet.
You don’t need to be mister charisma, but just think about things you find impotent to you and talk about them in a way that invites them I ask questions.

Another time I was randomly asked out by a girl I took a college class with: has never met her before, she had just sat next to me in class and said “we should go out.” So we did. That was a rare thing that never happened again: I always started the conversations after that with any girl. Just be clean, smell normal and have something to talk about that’s relevant to her or where you’re at.
For instance, I once dated a girl I met at universal studios. She worked in the one of the gift shops and I needed help putting back a shirt on a high shelf. She brought out a stick and told me she uses it because she’s short. I laughed and said “that’s okay, I’m also short. So we can be short together.” Then we talked about why I was there, that I was local, and some other random things and eventually I got her number. The key is to end the conversation early with promise of more interesting stuff to say as the reason for the number

I’ve had success on Twitter. But a lot of Twitter has to do with you being okay with long distance if you can’t meet someone close by. The key with Twitter is to start a conversation on a public tweet, usually replying to each other based on whatever thread was of interest, then adding a follow and saying “you’re interesting, I’ll follow you” or something like that. Then interact with her tweets in between other tweets. She can’t think you only use Twitter for her, or that you only use Twitter to hit up chicks. Definitely have a traceable Twitter record as she WILL be checking your timeline. And eventually you can get your luck with a DM.
You can always luck out and hit it off with her so well that you automatically start DMing on day one, but this has only happened about 4 times for me. Usually some work is involved, unless there was a reason for the DM. Like you mention a embarrassing photo of yourself or something or say “I own a ___ actually” then has that as an excuse to DM. Generally speaking, you want to get off Twitter with her as fast as possible. Try getting her Snapchat or her discord or whatever she uses most often. Asking for a phone number from Twitter is risky and should only be done if you’re talking up a mad storm

There are sure tell signs. The first one is how fast they reply to you. If they reply faster than 5 minutes, they’re engaged in the conversation.
Second, how long the convo lasts. If you are talking or an hour straight without any noticeable lulls, she’s really into you, especially if she starts initiating afterwards. I’ve had scenarios where I met a girl that day and we messaged the entire day and started messaging all day every day.

Generally speaking, when a girl is into you, they want to hear you talk and they want to show you their good sides. If she self deprecates, it’s so you can respond with flattery. If they want to talk about their hobbies, it’s because they want to open up to you. If she mentions she likes to cook, that’s an invitation to ask her what she last cooked or what her favorite dishes are, which is then an invitation to say what your favorites are and to subtly ask to go out to eat or to have her cook for you.
If she keeps eye contact with you while smiling, she’s interested, if she seems waiting to constantly reply and talk, she’s into you, if she seems like she wants to keep the conversation going, she’s also interested.
It’s all about knowing who you are, knowing what you’re about, and conveying that. It’s true, not every girl will care. But most will, and usually you can get by on the looks department as long as you’re groomed properly and dressed in a presentable manner. You can still wear jeans and a t shirt, just make sure they’re clean and they fit right.
each girl will say they got with me for a different reason, but the way I talked to them and how I approached each target mattered. This is something that takes experience.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>27923520
About a year and a half from getting my own Electrical Engineering bachelors. Good work getting through it.

Reading has been my favorite activity over the past year. I set a Goodreads goal to read 30+ books this year and I'm one book away from reaching it, after having had trouble reading more than one book every 3 months in the past. Given your situation philosophy might be best, as it'll let you see the world through a lot of different perspectives: Plato's dialogues are a great place to start, beginning with the Apology.
For fiction I'd recommend the My Struggle series by Karl Ove Knausgaard and The Magic Mountain by Thomas Mann. The former is a relatively recent retelling of the author's life with a lot of introspection, and the latter is about a German college grad visiting his sick cousin at a tuberculosis sanitorium in the Swiss alps. Getting audiobooks for those and playing marathonable games like Civilization 5 would be an easy way to pass the time.

>>27924912
What I learned is that lymph nodes get big for many reasons, it can be any kind of infection, not necessarily cancer. The only way to tell if you have cancer is with a biopsy.
The problem is that most doctors don't want to believe that young people have cancer. In my case during my first cancer it took me around a year to be hospitalized and 1 month inside the hospital for them to decide to do a lymph node biopsy.

Too bad that Hodgkin's lymphoma has a relative good chance of coming back in a 5 year period. I was unlucky and it came back after 6 years, sometimes I feel like it came back because of the 1-2 years of isolation due to covid. Isolation is terrible for health.
Thankfully Hodgkin's lymphoma is a "chill" cancer. I would rather have it than leukemia. Acute leukemia too is fucking terrible.

Let's hope things get better for us.

posts.sub: How to cope with mental illness and move on?
posts.com:
I suffer from recurring bouts of chronic depression, anxiety, ADHD (procrastination) and have to be medicated to function.
I am now a 22 year old sophomore in college studying my second-best liked major (pharmacy) instead of medicine, I still feel insecure about my mediocre grades in senior high school.
I failed to get myself to study for my senior high school diploma for 3 years, and my psychiatrist had tried every single combination of anti-depressant & anti-psychotic medications to change me. >>27924988
It's really common to struggle with telling people personal shit, man. I think most people who go to therapy really struggle with that (or we wouldn't need therapy lol). It's your therapist's job to help you to overcome that anxiety, and to help you to express yourself. I understand why you would feel apprehensive about going into therapy and putting yourself through that discomfort again, but this could potentially be really good for you. Sometimes having a good therapist can make opening up to others much easier. It's such an important lifelong skill to learn. Ultimately, it's your choice, but I do encourage you to give it another try.

Your last therapist sounds like a tit. Unfortunately, a lot of cunts in therapy are shit at their job. In the future, it might be a good idea to talk about your faith in the occult, and seek therapists who work holistically with the faith of their clients. Faith is obviously a huge part of your life, so it's important to find someone who can work with you on that. You dig? They don't have to SHARE your ideas, but the ability to see things from your perspective and work with you is crucial.
>It's literally their one fucking job lmao

You want some really solid advice? When you go into therapy, the HARDER something is for you to talk about, the more CRUCIAL it is that you talk about it.
If you really don't want to talk about your sexuality with your therapist, I hate to say it, but you NEED to talk about your sexuality with your therapist.
Think of your painful, awkward, uncomfortable thoughts as though they are wounds. The more painful it is to think/talk about something (eg: being gay), the larger that wound is, and the more likely that it'll cause you to bleed out. So THAT is the wound that needs patching up. You gotta talk about it, man.

Write a list of 2-4 major 'bruises'. Make those the focus of your therapy sessions.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>27923627
Bee the best version of yourself, faggot.

It sounds like you're just an anxious person. I hate to say it, but the only way to get better at this is via practice, and by building your self-esteem. Become a better person that you can be proud of. Start opening up little by little to the people closest to you. Ask a friend or family member to 'hold your hand' in social situations until you get confident enough to socialise on your own. Start writing up a list of pointers and conversation starters, just to prepare yourself for the future.

Remember above all else: People are invariably attracted to vulnerability. One of my friends has a HUGE circle of friends, purely because her ADHD ass can't keep her mouth shut. She overshares and tells jokes without thinking. And people fucking love that shit. I really appreciate it because she always manages to steer conversations in the craziest directions, just by having no filter.
It'll take a lot of practice, but try challenging your inhibitions and your filter. Start small. Even if your first step is by giving TWO word replies instead of just one.

It's ok to be a quiet person who listens more than they talk. Maybe that's just who you are. But you should definitely aim to at least give your one-word answers and then ask a follow-up question to let THEM talk instead.

posts.sub: Woman is madly in love with me, but I'm not that physically attracted to her.
posts.com:
I've known this woman for five years; she's stupid in love with me. I like her a lot too and would describe her as my best friend. She isn't ugly, in fact she gets a lot of male attention, but she just isn't exactly my type. I just don't feel deep physical attraction to her---I rarely feel this with anyone, I've only felt it maybe 2-3 times in my life.
But maybe feeling deep physical attraction is a meme and it isn't what counts in a long-term relationship. Looks fade and you grow old and disgusting regardless. I don't know.
She tells me daily that she'd marry me instantly if I asked. That all she wants is a quiet life with me and a lot of that appeals to me; I like the simplicity of it and just forgetting the world and things are very easy with her.
On the counter side, I'm not sure I want a life-long relationship. I like solitude and being alone. I've never had a proper, proper long-term relationship and have never lived with anyone. I think I get annoyed by other people pretty readily and the thought of having to wake up next to someone and deal with their presence doesn't appeal to me.
I think I'm conflicted about it because I really don't believe in the romanticized "perfect love" or "perfect relationship". I think relationships as a whole are pretty ugly and full of faults; maybe the faults I perceive in this situation are worth dealing with. It feels like things like deep physical attraction may be overrated (and, also, transient regardless). Maybe what I have with her is at good as it gets. Of course I'm not sure I even want a long-term relationship regardless, with anyone.
Another qualm I have is that while I've repeatedly told her I don't know what I want, I think she's really betting on me coming through in the end and that if I say "no" her whole world will fall apart. I'm worried she'll kill herself or something.
So yeah, what do?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>27924840
Cry a lot.

The last time I had to put a dog to sleep, it was the hardest I've ever cried. Plus, I started a terrible job the same day. It was tough.

I remember feeling super stressed out and depressed for about a week after that, but it slowly got better every day. Just allow yourself enough time to cope.

One thing that helps me cope is knowing that dogs don't have a perception of "fond memories" like we do. When you lose a pet, you often reminisce about all the good memories you have with that pet. Dogs don't think like this. They are very in-the-moment creatures. Your dog isn't going to be wistfully remembering her time with you as she passes away like in a movie.

As long as you're with her and she's calm when she passes, I think Daisy will pass away happy. The way they put dogs to sleep is very calming and gentle.

If she hasn't passed yet, I echo these anons:
>>27924870
>>27924877
My family tends to take a little trip to the park with our dogs and treat them to human food they normally can't have (stuff like french fries).

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>27925135
Plan be has 98-ish% effectiveness rate if taken 24 hours after sex.
After 24 hours, the effectiveness is reduced.
After 48 hours, it's very unreliable.
If she has diarrhoea or vomiting within 6 hours of swallowing the pill, she will need to buy another one, because it would not have been absorbed into her body.
Do not use plan B as your regular birth control method. It wreaks havoc on the body, and can fuck with your periods for a while. Instead, talk to your girl about getting on regular birth control (There are different types of CCP, copper IUDs, etc...) or look into getting the snip if you are sure you don't want kids at any time in the future.
Don't trust period apps - especially if she's taking Plan B or similar hormonal birth control at any point - that shit is unreliable at best when you've got regular periods. If she's taking anything that fucks with her hormones, the apps are a waste of time.
You probably don't need to hear this, but just in case: DON'T USE THE PULLOUT METHOD.

A man’s opportunities are never exhausted so long as other men (who are not his friends) possess millions of acres and thousands of tons of gold.
The guarded treasure halls and iron-clad temples of modern kings and presidents, high priests and millionaires, are positively the richest the world has ever known.
Bulging are they with the vast hoards of silver and diamonds and gold.
Here, then, is opportunity on a colossal scale. Here is the goal of the Caesars, Nebuchadnezzars and Napoleons in the days that are coming.
All is ready and prepared for them, even as in olden times.
Caesar carried off the treasures of Egypt, Greece, Gaul and Rome. Napoleon looted the money vaults of Venice, Vienna, Madrid, Berlin and Moscow. London only escaped him.
Nebuchadnezzar plundered the Temple of Zion, where the Jews kept all their deposits and drank his beer and wine out of Jehovah’s pots of gold.
Napoleon, Caesar, Nebuchadnezzar! They were three great men, were they not? And in this their greatness consisted — they seized their opportunities.

The natural world is a world of war; the natural man is a warrior; the natural law is tooth and claw. All else is error. A condition of combat everywhere exists. We are born into a perpetual conflict. It is our inheritance even as it was the heritage of previous generations. This “condition of combat” may be disguised with the holy phrases of St. Francis, or the soft deceitful doctrines of a Kropotkin or Tolstoi, but it cannot be eventually evaded by any human being or any tribe of human beings. It is there and it stays there , and each man (whether he will or not) has to reckon with it. It rules all things; it governs all things; it reigns over all things and it decides all who imagine policemanized populations, internationally regulated tranquility, and State organized industrialism so joyful, blessed and divine.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Virtue is rewarded in this world, remember. Natural law makes no false judgments. Its decisions are true and just, even when dreadful. The victor gets the gold and the land every time. He also gets the fairest maidens, the glory tributes. And — why should it be otherwise? Why should the delights of life go to failures and cowards? Why should the spoils of battle belong to the unwarlike? That would be insanity, utterly unnatural and immoral.

Behold the crucifix, what does it symbolize? Pallid incompetence hanging on a tree.
Lo, I hear the fighters coming Over hill and dale and plain.
With the battle cry of ages In a Rebel world again.
Who’d forge their swords to plow-shares, Shall sweat in bitter yokes,
The free-born race and fearless Must deal out battle strokes.
In the wars of the Great Caesar, and Grim Hannibal, in the times of Belzchazzar, the Pharaohs and all; the days of Rienzi and Roland the Bold; all banners are waving for women and gold.
It is might against might, remember, by land and sea, man against man, money against money, brains against brains, and — everything to the winner.

posts.name: Anonymous

In this arid wilderness of steel and stone I raise up my voice that you may hear.
To the East and to the West I beckon. To the North and to the South I show a sign — Proclaiming “Death to the weakling, wealth to the strong.”
Open your eyes that you may hear, O! men of mildewed minds and listen to me, ye laborious millions!
For I stand forth to challenge the wisdom of the world; to interrogate the “laws” of man and of “God.”
I request reasons for your Golden Rule and ask the why and wherefore of your Ten Commands.
Before none of your printed idols do I bend in acquiescence and he who saith “thou shalt” to me is my mortal foe.
I demand proof over all things, and accept (with reservations) even that which is true.
I dip my forefinger in the watery blood of your impotent mad-redeemer (your Divine Democrat — your Hebrew Madman) and write over his thorn-torn brow, “The true prince of Evil — the king of the Slaves!”
No hoary falsehood shall be a truth to me — no cult or dogma shall encramp my pen.
I break away from all conventions. Alone, untrammeled. I raise up in stern invasion the standard of Strong.
I gaze into the glassy eye of your fearsome Jehovah, and pluck him by the beard — I uplift a broad-axe and split open his worm-eaten skull.
I blast out the ghastly contents of philosophic whited sepulchres and laugh with sardonic wrath.
Then reaching up the festering and varnished facades of your haughtiest moral dogmas, I write thereon in letters of blazing scorn: — “Lo and behold, all this is fraud!”

Do I just gotta find purpose or dedicate myself? And if so, how the hell does anyone summon the willpower to achieve that?

Genuinely afraid when I hit 30 to look back at what I haven't accomplished...

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Sometimes there isn't ONE easy answer for a general sense of failure, foreboding, and possible insecurity. The same way it's possible that money and the perfect woman WON'T make your life better, its possible that something more simple CAN.

Firstly, 30 isn't old. There are so many people that truly discover themselves and discover their success past 30.

Secondly, for better or worse, the things that sound cliche are generally the things that help us in life. Exercise, hobbies, socialization, and having a career goal regardless of whether it includes education or not.

If you feel zero motivation, severe apathy, or depression, don't be afraid to get professional help. Many people start on low dose antidepressants and don't need them at all a year down the line. Everyone needs something different so the hardest part is finding what it is that can help you. Wishing you the best of luck!

posts.sub: My parents lied to me about having a mental disorder.
posts.com:
I have spent most of my childhood being told that I don't have a disability, despite having been diagnosed with ADHD since childhood. For a while, my parents treated me with Ritalin, but they screwed around with the dosages very frequently. They were concerned about the medication "changing my personality" but did everything they could to stop me from developing a tolerance. Then, they kept changing which meds I took, and then decided they didn't want me on it anymore. Finally, they tried to convince me that I never had a disability. Over the years, I found out that my father has a lot of mental problems which I was never told about.

My father thought (at some point) that he might have schizophrenia, and he has also suspected that other people in the family have it as well; based on my conversations with other family members (purely on my dad's side of the family), they suffer from having severe manic episodes, during which they experience symptoms which overlap with schizophrenia, but these symptoms stop once the manic episodes stop. Also, they have histories of severe depressive episodes, and they have hinted at the *possibility* that there was a suicide somewhere in the family as a result of severe depression.

Here is where things get more difficult for me: my father only sought treatment for half of his disability (he received SSRIs for "depression") and frequently went off treatments during his manic phases; he grew to mistrust doctors and stopped getting help altogether. After these experiences, he also stopped me from getting treatment for having ADHD. In addition, he also abused my mother (and both parents regularly abused me as a child). In addition, my father remarked (several times) that he wishes he "hadn't gotten me vaccinated" and "I seemed fine before, but not after." If this isn't an admission he thought I have ASD, then I don't know what is.

Financially, my dad is still leeching off my mom, and I hate that. What are some options?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
1. vaccines don't cause autism or have any connection thereto. This isn't up for debate, that's a medical fact.

2. ADHD is not autism either.

3. You described classic bipolar disorder for your father and other family members, including the paranoia, distrust of doctors and going off medication. Bipolar disorder is hereditary. Psychosis is common during BPD manic cycles.

4. Children with Bipolar Disorder are sometimes misdiagnosed as having ADHD due to symptoms overlap in children/adolescence.

5. These things aren't disabilities.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>27923770
Beer is very varied. It's possible you just don't like that brand or that type of beer. Experiment and find a beer that you enjoy.

If it's the alcohol taste you dislike, that's gonna require some experimentation too.

Move on to something fruity instead - they're usually more pleasant. Sangria or wine are usually nice. Vodka or white rum with orange juice is nice. You might want to try different juices with different alcohol, to see how you feel about it. If you're unsure what to make, look up some classic mixes online.
It takes some experimentation to find out what you like. If you're not sure what to try first, ask your mates what they like to drink, and maybe swap sips of your mates' drinks at parties to find out what you enjoy.

I used to fucking HATE the taste of alcohol when I started drinking. I found that I can stand stronger drinks if they're 'refreshing', though. Eg: rum and orange juice is a favourite. White wine is nice. The colder your drink is, the nicer it tastes. Shit, sometimes having a cool glass of water between alcoholic drinks can make a positive difference.

If worst comes to worst and you find yourself not enjoying anything you drink, you may need to stick to shots instead. Jelly donut shots are nice. Bacardi and midori are also good.
Or you may simply need to bite the bullet and sip your alcohol straight with ice. It'll taste foul if you hate the taste of alcohol, but you won't have to drink quite so much. You also won't need to pee as frequently, so that's cool.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>27924836
Also, don't choose your alcohol based on price. Don't buy cheap shit to avoid a loss. And don't buy cheap shit, hoping the price reflects the quality. It often doesn't. And if you dislike alcohol or beer, you may find yourself disliking the objectively good stuff too - quality be damned.
Instead, do some research online and look into beers or other drinks that people enjoy, "despite not normally liking that type of drink". Those are probably the ones you want.
